messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] Re: homemade paper/Digest Number 1382
messages.msgSnippet: I iron the paper dry.  It only takes a few minutes and then you can start painting, writing,  whatever. Deb L.
messages.messageBody:
I iron the paper dry. It only takes a few minutes and then you can start
painting, writing, whatever.
Deb L.

On Mon, 27 Aug 2001 16:18:58 -0700 megates@... writes:
> Where do you put the paper to dry? I have a gorgeous kit that my mom
> found at a yard sale. It has the frame/screen and a bunch of REALLY
> nice
> paper (lintners?) that you are supposed to tear up to make the new
> paper...
>
> I have also been saving lint when it comes out a nice color.
>
> We haven't made the paper yet, because I don't know where I'll put
> it to
> dry. It's often breezy here.
>
> Mary Ellen
> Success is a process of living.
> It's stopping for the moments of beauty, of pleasure, the moments of
> peace.
> Success is not a destination that you ever reach.
> Success is the quality of the journey.

messages.subject: Re: homemade paper/Digest Number 1382
messages.msgSnippet: Where do you put the paper to dry?  I have a gorgeous kit that my mom found at a yard sale.  It has the frame/screen and a bunch of REALLY nice paper
messages.messageBody:
Where do you put the paper to dry? I have a gorgeous kit that my mom
found at a yard sale. It has the frame/screen and a bunch of REALLY nice
paper (lintners?) that you are supposed to tear up to make the new
paper...

I have also been saving lint when it comes out a nice color.

We haven't made the paper yet, because I don't know where I'll put it to
dry. It's often breezy here.

Mary Ellen
Success is a process of living.
It's stopping for the moments of beauty, of pleasure, the moments of
peace.
Success is not a destination that you ever reach.
Success is the quality of the journey.
